Good point of view. The place, located in Buda, is not that high but without doubt interesting, because you can also look at the other side of the hill. I like this attraction.
Castle Hill. We visited the beautiful gardens of the castle hill.you can see from there Beautiful view from the city's Pest side.

Fun, but not that much to do. The views are great and there are a few fun cafes, but overall there isn't that much to do on Castle Hill. Mainly we walked around and took pictures. The views were worth the trip, but I think there is so much more that could be done with this area.
Great spot to visit. Worth spending a couple hours exploring the grounds and beautiful church in this charming part of Budapest. Lovely views from this area as well.

Rich in Tradition. This is a neat place to visit--across from the river from the hustle and bustle, offering beautiful views, and steeped in history. We got very lucky the day we visited as a Hungarian military band unit was performing what appeared to be a daily ritual. The pomp and circumstance was neat! (It was around 4 PM, so maybe make sure to be there in the late afternoon during your visit!)

Great place to visit. We had a guide take us on a walking tour around this castle. Their are lovely gardens, beautiful staircase, monuments, St. Matthias Church, shops and Cafes. You can take the funicular up the hill or there is a staircase or elevator down the street from chain bridge.
Visit the Gallery!t. As over 70's we got to see the excellent Modigliano and Picasso exhibitions, free of charge. Gallery is one of the best we have visited

It seems like chaos, but.... It's worth the climb. The view is spectacular. Sit for a bit... grab a coffee or a beer and watch the people doing selfies. Then spend some time musing over the view downtime hill. This city is full of stories. Listen to them.

Castle Hill on the Buda Side of Budapest. Castle Hill is beautiful, filled with amazing Austro Hungarian architecture and buildings that speak of the former glory of Budapest before the country was taken over by the Communists and was a part of the post war Eastern block of nations. Castle Hill just may be, next to the outstanding buildings and institutions in Vienna, the capital of the former Austro Hungarian Empire, the largest and the most remarkable monument to local and. central European history. Across the Danube on the Pest Side of the city, one can see another extraordinary building, the Parliament which also originates from that part of central European history when Hungary together with Austria "ruled" over a large portion of the European homeland. Today, Castle Hill houses many institutions, restaurants, museums and cultural performance spaces. On one of my visit to Budapest, I went to the Castle Hill, that is to say I walked up to the Castle Hill to get the view of the city and to attend a modern dance performance. It was terrific.

A tourist must visit. The Castle Hill of Buda has many restored historical buildings. Most were damaged at the end of WWII and restored according to historical pictures. There are a few that stick out like sore thumbs but the rest are gems.
Lots to see. There is so much to see at castle hill in Budapest. There's so much history here in such a small area! Also places to shop and also enjoy some Hungarian pastries, coffee and tea.

A stunning architectural piece. The art work and current Picasso & Modigliani exhibition are well worth a visit. The national collection of artwork is exceptional and art lovers and experts will love this place. The queues to get in were long and the staff could have been more helpful by opening up more ticket desks instead of just watching the queue grow! Castle Hill is a log way up so use the funicular railway or free lifts located round the area.

The tourist spots were all sold out to restaurants. I came here in November of 2015 and in spite of being overpriced, it was worth it for the pictures you could get of the city. I came here today and it was a HUGE disappointment. Literally all of the good spots to take pictures were blocked off on castle hill to make over priced restaurants that would not allow people in to take pictures. My friend and I kept walking around looking for a good spot to take pictures and place after place was blocked off to make restaurants that were so overpriced nobody wanted to eat there. We walked up one castle turret to find that it was also blocked and turned into a restaurant. I commented to my friend who was there for the first time- "I am so disappointed. In November, this was a great place to take pictures. Now, they have turned one of the top tourist destinations into a overpriced restaurant industry. What a shame." An old man turned around and looked at me and said "You are 100% correct. This is terrible." There were several tourist groups that I saw who were disappointed that all of the good access points were closed off for big industries to make money on overpriced restaurants. There are many cool things to do in Budapest. Going to the Castle Hill is no longer one of those things.

Magnificent view. Really interesting place. Went up by steam powered small cabins on rail. Well worth the cost if you don't like to look as you completed a full marathon when you go by stairs. Breathtaking view over Budapest. Can really recommend going here and se the sun set over this beautiful town.

Lots to do and see.. There is so much to do here you could spend hours here. To get here you can either take the Funicular to the top or walk - we took the Funicular up and walked back down. Well worth a visit even if it is just for the views.

So many things. Castle, museum, very nice point of vue,...
What a beautiful place !
Use the old funicular to climb.
One of the best thing to do in Budapest

Popular District. An area of Budapest that includes Buda Palace, Fisherman's Bastion, Mathias Church.
plus shops and restaurants. A must see part of the city with super views over the Danube and Pest.

Huge place, interesting architecture and monuments. You can walk up, you can use a kind of a railway, you can use taxi. Best choice is a railway up and walking down. On Sunday and during the tourist season you will have long queue at the entrance of the cabin of the railway. During your way up you have fine views to the Chain bridge and to the Pest town with parliament and churches. On the top you can go right to the old castle area or left to the palace and National gallery. I propose you to walk around when weather permits. You will see several fountains and monuments. Later, you can enter to the National gallery. You need at least an hour for the palace – without visiting collections and two hours for the castle area, towers, archeological findings, church.

Amazing. Such a lovely building from both sides of the river. We went over once and walked around the building (it's massive) and got some great pictures. The architecture is super and well worth a visit.

Stunning views of the city!. Castle hill has several paths up or a team that takes you to the top. The buildings are great to see, but it is the panoramic views of the city that make this such a great place to visit in Budapest even if you only have limited time in the city.

Lots to see with plenty of excellent restaurants. During the day museums galore. Many people including most foreign ambassadors live in Buda close by Castle Hill. There are plenty of museums including the National Gallery, a military museum and even a small musical instrument museum. Various churches, the old palace and the Presidential palace. Lots of good restaurants and lots of points with fabulous views of Pest and the Danube bellow.

Great views of city. Stay for sunset if you can. Glorious views of city and the river. Lots to do with little shops and restaurants. Housing fans will want to stop by the little museum and magic show. Great Fun!
Nice place. Castle hill is on the pest side of Budapest. It is a tourist destination and offers beautiful view of the river and the surroundings.

Best view of Pest in the city. Maintenance is performed once or twice a month on the permanent collection, so check the calendar before you visit. The grounds are open everyday and it's worth the long walk around. The views of Pest are breathtaking and the area is large enough to take photos without other people in them.

Gorgeous area. This has always been my favorite part of the city. The architecture is varied and beautiful. The palace is now a magnificent art museum. the Modigliani exhibit is the finest show of his,work that I have ever seen. The cathedral is extraordinary.

Lovely old building with nice views.. Impressive building with nice picturesque views along the ramparts. Regular art exhibitions we're told, Modigliani was on when we were there. Don't bother with the vernacular railway, stay on the no. 16 bus to the top. We bought return tickets for the railway, didn't use the return part.
Buda side tour. A part of history not to be missed ... this is for the history and architecture lovers... Buda side gem

Lovely Part Of Buda. The district is lovely and very picturesque, housing the palace, fisherman's bastion, mattias church and many little cafés etc....super views over the river.
We got here by taking tram 4 or 6 from the Hotel Palazzo Zichy, all the way. You can also take a funicular from the base to the place but the queues are ridiculous.

Must see. Stunning, breathtaking, wow. Be prepared for a trek though. Best views of the city we were lucky enough to stay up here and it did not disappoint. Plenty of cafe, bar, restaurants, and gift shops as well as the big places.

Great sightseeing. If you are staying in Budapest you can easily walk across the chain bridge and then either walk up (not too bad in March but didn't feel up to it in the July heat) or you can take the funicular. About 15 minute queue when we went in July. When we visited in spring we saw the guard change but they weren't out in July although it was about 36 degrees so probably too hot. You can walk around to fishermans bastion or the Hungarian national gallery

Quite good. Interesting and historic part of Budapest. Home of many must-see places of the city. Nice selection of gifts and souvenirs.Great views of the city from many spots.Some reconstruction works are being done here and there which somewhat brings down the overal impression.

Lovey views. We went up the left side of Castle Hill, it kinda felt like a really long windy driveway. It was a great walk and there were some neat stone areas along the way. The castle itself is now a museum and we didn't actually go in it, but we did walk around and enjoy the fountains, statues, and beautiful buildings. Once at the top we walked through a main archway After that we saw where the prime minister lives, walked along the streets and saw lots of shops and then arrived over at Fisherman's Bastion.
Night Run Budapest. Visiting the Castle is always a pleasure, but running the start of a half marathon by night makes it even more special in this historical place!

Visit at Night & Day - just stunning. Great part of Buda district ... Castle Hill is the tourist highlight of the left bank. Trinity Square has St Matthius Cathedral & the Tower which is position A for photos & views down the Danube. In a part of the Tower we saw a film downstairs in the basement on the history of Hungary - very interesting, especially the story of "The White Stag", a Hungarian creation myth about how twins Hanor & Magor founded the country by chance whilst out hunting by meeting & marrying two Sarmatian princesses - thus uniting the Huns, the Magyars & the Alans. An enjoyable & educational diversion. Make sure you see the castle by night ... when lit up it is at its spectacular best!

Day or Night is a Magnificent Building and Area. the Castle Hill is amazing both during the day and night - the views of the Pest area the best. Strolling afterwards through the old Buda town is very nice

Must-visit! View and grand old castles.. A must-visit spot. Fantastic view of River Danube, Chain Bridge, and Pest side of the city. Grand old buildings and castles. Charming old cobble stone winding streets. You can take a leisurely stroll. Touristy and lots of souvenir shops. Bars, cafes, and restaurants are all super expensive. You can get here by walking across the Chain Bridge, cable car, or bus.

Pleasant, scenic, essential walking tour!. We really enjoyed our leisurely walking tour of the Castle hill area of Budapest. Our lovely guide, VIKI, is beautiful inside and out. She was totally receptive to our requests and time constraint needs. VIKI smoothly adapted and customized the tour for us. We saw the beautiful sites, learned a lot about the history of the city and Hungary, and enjoyed it on a casual walking tour. Lovely coffee and cake break in the German area, and even perfect photo stops! Ask for VIKI!

NOT TO BE MISSED. Castle Hill is not to be missed. The entire area is absolutely amazing with gorgeous buildings and stunning views. It is quite wonderful to stroll along the streets, looking at the architecture...doors, windows, embelishments, courtyards and stopping along the way for a drink at some outside café. History just oozes out of every corner, going back hundreds, indeed a thousand plus years. Yes, it is touristy with lots of shops hawking goods to all, and crowded, but don't let that stop you from spending at least half a day here, even better, spend a whole day!
A great area to explore. We spent a half day up here. There were many musuems and places to walk . It was raining the day we went so was fairly quiet. The ride up in the funicular was fun
Beautiful. Beautiful area, most defiantly worth a visit. We spent a fair few hours around here. Highly recommended.

Amazing views... Its well worth a visit. We walked over the chain bridge and rode the funicular to the top : Huf 1800 for a return ticket. The views are spectacular. Lovely gardens and some beautiful statues. There are places to eat and buy ice cream and souvenirs. Loved it.

Outstanding! . First time in Budapest and highly impressed! Had a private guide (highly recommend a guided tour) who gave us many background stories about the area. Beautiful views of the city and very impressive architecture.

Disappointing . We thought we could tour the castle, but it's just a conglomerate of museums. I guess the upside is that the views of the city are nice. I would do something else if you are in the city for a short time like Memento Park, the Parliament building or take a cheap boat cruise to take in the gorgeous city.

Some area under renovation . It's huge place with many museum and building. I didn't visit National Gallery but I went to Hungarian Historical Museum. From this hill we can see beautiful Buda and Pest side, especially the bridges. If you want to go to toilet, you have to pay €1. So I came to the restaurant and buy a drink. Every guest have a facility to go to the toilet for free (the staff will give you one toilet coupon)From this hill, you can continue to Mattyas church and Fisherman Bastion by walk. It's around 400m. So, you've better buy only one way funicular ticket (800 HUF) if you want to go walk to the Mattyas Church and take a bus for descend (it's cheaper than with funicular) especially if you use Budapest Card (Budapest card isn't valid for using funicular)
The royal castle. A wonderful view of the city from the royal castle on the Buda hill, amazing location and a very impressive building, worth while visiting

A must but .... Of course this is the most dominant building on the Budapest skyline and it's a place you have to go both for the castle itself and for the views of the city. We took the funacular up and down and if you haven't been on one of them before it's worth doing although the queues can be long (we bought the ticket as part of the Big Bus tour and they promised we would skip the queue and indeed we did.. The guy gave us the tickets and skipped us right to the front of the queue for the next car).We didn't go into the Castle beyond the main entrance, but if we had had more time we would have done so. Outside, the sheer size of the castle is amazing, and there are great views over the city as well.

History everywhere. The ancient Castle of Buda everything is historical Not only the majestic Coronation Church, but every house,building,court, alley have close to 1000 year history. One can spend hours just walking the old streets, reading the plaques, and admire the skill of the builders hundreds of years ago. The Royal Palace and National Gallery are near as well.Only complaint is that there are too many tourists at times, especially at the Fishermans Bastion

You can't go to Budapest without seeing Castle Hill. A perfect place to spend half a day walking around...cafés, restaurants, specialty shops, museums, historical buildings and churches and, of course, the castle itself. The whole area exudes Hungarian imperial charm. Furthermore, the view of the river and Parliament is incredible. Great monuments line the walled perimeter overlooking the riverbank. Don't forget to ride the funicular back down to the bridge.

Disappointed . The view of outside is excellent. So we went inside. It is expensive but not worth it. 20 minutes before closing time, a lady wouldn't let us to enter one of the halls because they want to close on time. I haven't never seen such a service.

Took a tour to the top. We saw the changing of the guards while we were on tour. This is a very huge Castle with many tourists--so go early. Walk around to appreciate the size and the detail. You can walk the whole area while you are up on top. Then we walked down and across the river for more sightseeing.

Royal Castle first completed in 1265.. Also known as Buda Castle, is the historical castle and palace complex of the Hungarian kings in Budapest. In the past, it has been called Royal Palace and Royal Castle. It is worth visiting these huge building, richly decorated and with a majestic architecture.
A lot to see. Plenty to see. Royal Palace, National Gallery, History Museum, Matyas Church, Fishermen's Bastion. Plan to take 3 hours.
Fantastic. Visited Budapest in March 2016 on a 4 day city break. Had a great time around castle hill and the surrounding area. Loads to see,great views and friendly people. Will be returning soon.

Superb.. There is a lot to see and do and exploring Castle Hill took me an entire day. If you don’t have much time, visit Trinity Square, Matthias Church (Mátyás templom) and Fishermen’s Bastion (Halászbástya). Various events are held at Castle Hill year round. Superb.

Beautiful view of the castle from the Pest side of the Danube. We went to Castle Hill as part of a city tour at the conclusion of our Viking River Cruise. The Castle is very impressive. You have some great views from atop Castle Hill. From our hotel on the Pest side we had a great view of the Castle at sunrise as we awakened early for our flight home.
Beautiful buildings. There is very much to see in Castle Hill: old, amazing buildings, museums, many cafeterias etc. You can walk there from Pest or use the public transport.

Nice wiew over the Danube. It is wonderful sight over the river to specially Pest side,and to hill Gellert. Try to timing your visit up there in evening,so you can see city with lights on. It is so beautiful!
So very regal.. Really worth a trip the whole castle hill is lovely but this place is like something from Game of Thrones, it is huge , covered in courtyards and fountains, and ver accessible.

Excellent way to spend a day. Lovely walk over one of several bridges admiring the view of Budapest, simply beautiful. Not too steep a walk up the hill as winding and gradual. Furnicular railway an option. Picasso exhibition on currently. Hospital in the Rock very worth a visit whilst at the top of the hill as is Ruszwurm coffee shop. The most delicious cakes and coffee and only 5 mins away.

History of Budapest. This is a place related with historical Austro-Hungarian Imperium. The Emeperors from Wien found that Budapest is a strategic place for their necesities so they build this Castle in Buda. Eperess Sisi were very strongly connected with Budapest and hungarian people. Is very nice building inside and outside with lots of statues and paintings. Inside you can visit arts galleries.

Beautiful View of Pest. Covering only the terrace outside the castle: there is a very impressive equestrian statue of Prince Eugene of Savoy who must have played a major role in the re-conquest of Buda (from the Turks),yet in the official monumental painting inside the National Gallery he is just one of several generals supporting the leader of the expedition, some Habsburg Prince. I like this juxtaposition: the "people" knew all the while who had done the work, never mind that a Habsburg led the eventual procession into liberated Buda...

Kiss the Princess!!. This is a very romantic spot to visit by night but well get there. Located on the hills of Buda this 13th century castle is magnificent and gorgeous. It's baroque architecture let's you imagine all the stories and adventures it might had seen already and the view to Pest side is absolutely breath taking. There are exhibitions year long and other activities, but if you want to seat down at its walls and contemplate the world, this is a place to be. By evening its lights transforms the place into one of the most romantic spots in all Budapest. The golden lights makes the ambience smooth and luxurious, you become a Knight looking for the princess to kiss. Highly recommended, free to visit the outdoors, not crowded though a tourist spot. Souvenirs available and you can even try the art of archery right by the entrance. Maybe you can hit the heart of your Lady to be!

Great views. The Hop On Hop Off bus stops right across the street of the funicular. We decided to take the elevator up (free) instead of waiting in long line to purchase a funicular ticket. The view up top was spectacular. There were many spots for nice pictures.

Fantastic view at the top!. This was one of the most beautiful attractions in Budapest. It was a walking distance from Sofitel Chain Bridge hotel where we were staying. We took the funicular to the top. We spent around 4 to 5 hours exploring most of the attractions there including Buda Castle, Fisherman's Bastion, Mathias Church, .. and much more. If you can make it to the Liberty Statue then you can get a fantastic view for the Danube River and the Chain Bridge. At night, the view is even more phenomenal. Definitely this is a must see.

Nice castle form Sissi the Hungaro-Austrian quuen. Nice castle from outside, nice museum inside but unfortunately the communist destroyed the interior and you have nothing really from the past inside. This is always the same senario with these idiots, they try to delete all the past and specially from the best past. A shame!
Just seat on the grass. We waited for our friends sitting directly on the grass near the Castle. We also visited the Castle itself. Very nice place for spending the time.

Incredible palace and national gallery. Looks amazing from every direction and involves a good climb to get there or use the funicular train. Inside is the national gallery of many paintings and sculptures - you have to pay but well worth a visit. Outside are many walks along cobbled streets, paths and battlements, and don't forget the history museum on the south side.

King of the hill☺. Crossing Chain Bridge from the Pest side, and either taking the #16 bus to the top or walking the winding—and winded—streets or paths, Castle Hill affords far more than panoramic views of Budapest. There are dozens of attractions atop this plateau, primarily Buda Castle, but there’s also Fisherman’s Bastion, Mathias Church, the Plague Column, and much more. An entire day can be enjoyed here, there’s so much to do. The art museum housed inside Buda Castle alone consumed six hours of my day, much of that with the Picasso Exhibit.

Illumination at night is brilliant. Visit in the day and see the views, changing of the guards and museums but go again at night to see the real scale of the buildings as they are all illuminated.Walk around to appreciate the size and the detail.The size of the monuments and detail were amazing.

Explore it in the evening. This is a beautiful and lively place to hang out in the evenings. There is not as much 'everyday life' on the Buda hill as there is in Pest side, but it is great to explore the Roman ruins and the little gardens of the castle on a long summer evening.

VERY INTERESTING. Castle Hill is reached by either walking up the many paths leading to Castle Hill, the public bus from Szell Kalman ter or, the best option via the funicular at the foot of the Chain Bridge. Located on Castle Hill are the Royal Palace (museum), Fishermen's Bastion, Mathias Church, the National Museum of Military History and many other museums and tourist sites. Scattered throughout are numerous shops and restaurants. Castle Hill provides a panoramic view (and photo op) for Parliament, the Danube River, the Chain Bridge and surrounding Budapest. Be sure to catch the changing of the guard that takes place on the hour every hour (believe starting at 1000). Best viewing point is the small square right by the top of the funicular station. We stayed directly across from Castle Hill at the Intercontinental Hotel and had a great view of the Palace and St Mathias from our large triple picture window.
Another great place. Plenty to look around at here and depending upon the time you have it is worth s visit. Plenty of photo opportunities here.
The views!. If you cant make it to the Liberty Statue then this view of the Danube is just as good, you really can see for miles. Walking up here is beautiful, probably more fun than the funicular.

A real let down. I have visited the castle in Prague & was expecting something similar but was really disappointed. Building work was taking place, it was crowded with tour groups who had no consideration for others & lots of traffic. New buildings with no style spoil the feel of the place & the views from the top don't blow you away. The small market & the hospital in the rock museum were it's only saving graces. Over rated in my opinion

One beautiful building after the Other.....Budapest shows her Best!!!. Castle Hill is the place to go when in Budapest...Beautiful in itself and a great place to visit...the views of the city are magnificent from the Hill. Best place for photos....
Great Views. Great views of the city and the Danube the castle and its sourrounding area well worth a visit in itself
Regular castle. Not great from inside - plus you have to park at fishermens bastion to get here. But again a balcony inside the castle givse probably the best view in budapest.
Visit Castle Hill. Great way to spend some time touring the grounds. Take the funicular to the top at a small fee. This was included in our Hop On Hop Off bus ticket.
Incredible views!. The views at the top of Castle Hill are phenomenal. Getting the funicular up is a great idea and these were by far my favourite views of the city from my trip to Budapest.

Beautiful Must see views of Budapest.. The walk from the Pest side to the Buda side where this Castle stands is well worth the effort. Those that cannot walk up the hill can take a steep Hong Kong style cable car up to the top. The view that awaits you is amazing. The Danube down below with all the bridges that cross the mighty Danube in front of your eyes. Budapest is a Diamond in the Rough. It seems it has just woken from its slumber behind the Iron Curtain and now has its first chance to spread its wings and be everything it should have been. Love Budapest

Beautiful at night.. First day, I walked around at night. This building was so beautiful. Then next day I watched it from too of the hill. The dorm form is so nice. From all of aspect, you should watch this. Of you get yellow team, you can get to there.
A brilliant view. We spent a good 3 hours up on the castle taking in the views and visiting the museum which is excellent value for money. It really is a must visit when in Budapest.

Pretty with great views.. Don't forget your camer. The location offers fantastic views of Buda and the Danube; well worth the schlep up there for this alone. Due to time constraints, this was a snap and dash visit.
Top site. Take the funicular up and walk back down -- museum is worth doing depending on special exhibits -- spectacular views in all directions

Stunning Architecture. Gorgeous and worth an evening visit too -- lights at night just beautiful as well. If you take a river cruise -- best way to see at night. We traveled through Viking and then extended our stay -- excellent trip.
imposing building overlooking the danube. Didn't go inside but the grounds were impressive. The view of the Danube and of past were absolutely amazing. It was worth asking up there

Lots to see and do at Buda Castle. Be sure to allot several hours to walk thru the Castle Hill district which is also referred to as Buda Castle. Of course, it is on a hill overlooking the Danube and Pest with great views of the city and river especially at night. You can get there by walking, taking the hop-on hop-off bus, or ride to the top on the funicular located at the 0 km marker near the Chain Bridge. There is much to see and do as Buda Castle contains The Royal Palace along with many museums, cafes, shops, churches and even some private residences and hotels.

Gorgeous views from the hill -- and walking around here is also interesting. We took the funicular up the hill (which was really fun) for the amazing views of Pest. The views from the river up the hill are also outstanding - by day and night, too, when the entire area is lit up. Actually those views are spectacular!The line for the funicular up can be very long. Our guide had us there before 9 am, so we had no wait, but told us that later it could stretch for over an hour. The ride up is about $5 US. The grounds of the castle are undergoing some renovation, but you can see the original footings. Work is going on around that area but it is still walkable. Start here and walk to the big church and square, then up to the walls for more spectacular views. There are many quaint shops and cafes around the area as well. In the height of the tourist season it gets pretty crowded, so timing your visit to be at the funicular first thing in the morning will make it more pleasant. The gardens are lovely and very well maintained. Lots of places for photo ops!
Beautiful at night. The Castle grounds are lovely. I would recommend walking around at night and soaking up the views of the city.

History and beauty rolled into one.. Take your time and walk through this wonderful place enjoy the fantastic views over the Danube, look up as you walk at the detail in the statues, each has a story to tell. Fisherman Bastian is a short walk from the Castle.

Buda Castle. We walked up and down the stairs as we didn´t want to pay a fortune for the cabletour. the stairs op the hill requires a good physical form and good shoes, t but it is not too demanding for someone with normal walking ability.

What a beauty !. The visit to Castle Hill in Budapest is a must ! Apart from the most amazing views,the visit to the Castle is a must. You HAVE to see the breathtaking Picasso and the Modigliani exhibitions, as well as the national art treasures of Hungary ! And after seeing all these amazing art treasures, spoil yourself to a delicious luncheon in the gardens !
Must see. Beautiful grand old imperial buildings and a breathtaking view across the Danube towards the Parliament. Come for a visit and walk down the hill towards Pest.

Long walk UP!. Nice area and probably one of the nicest places to get great panorama photos of Budapest. We did not go in to the castle. There was a Picasso exhibit going on inside . Our tour guide told us that unless we were interested in seeing Picasso, there wasn't much else to see inside, so we just walked around outside and admired the view of Pest from afar.
Feel the history . You can feel the history if you look around. Inspiring place, good for a walk and to think and collect some energy from the monument.

Can't visit Budapest and skip this one.. A mandatory visit. It's a very pleasant whole / half day program, with many sights to see, and nice restaurants / cafés to boost. The view from up there is amazing, the place feels like a citadel. It's very curious for me to think that people actually live there, in this old town.

There is so much to do.... Buda Castle is not really a castle so much as an entire city surrounded by walls. There is a fantastic museum, great things to see, homes, businesses, and of course restaurants. I found a great antique shop and was able to relieve the owner of some lovely items at a very reasonable price. But plan on spending enough time. The museum alone will take several hours, and walking around the residential part takes some time as well, and makes you very hungry and thirsty!
Another good view over the city. The distract of the castle is nice and filled with colored buildings. It also has a panoramic view over the Danube.

Please put more signage! . A Massive complex but unsure where you are, how to get where you want to go due to lack of info and signage confused us all the way up - but we made it eventually. Oh don't get me wrong, it's so very beautiful and well maintained so you will forget all about it in no time. If you don't have unlimited 4G data plan, get it now. cos you need Google maps!

not really a castle now . Apparently it is the castle district, not really a castle now. the building you see is an art museum and the area on top of the hill used to be within castle walls. there is a church and a nice view. the funicular ride down the hill is overpriced for a short minute ride down.

Yes Yes Yes Go To The Castle. We hadn't put the Castle on our list of things to see in our 3 days in Budapest and I don't know why. We "stumbled" upon by taking a Segway trip accompanied by a guide for 90 minutes. Best £37 I spent in Budapest. It's a great way to pack a lot of sightseeing into a short amount of time, and quite fun too. Not suitable for small children or the infirm of course but otherwise very good.The Castle history is fascinating and the City has clearly spent a fortune getting it back to it's former glory, especially after the ravages of WWII. Just along the road is the National Museum which, when we went, was housing a Picasso exhibition with over 100 of his works. Cost about £10 to get in which was incredible value. Well worth checking what they have on if you decide to go. A very pleasant part of the City and not as busy as the Pest side.

Amazing view to the Pest side. The view from the castle hill on the Pest side of the city is amazing.Don't hesitate to go their to see everything this hill has too offer.Also, take a walk on the rampart of the castle and go down to the castle's garden.

Budapest anniversary visit. Try the funicular to get up to the top of Castle Hill but be aware that long queues can form to get on. The Musuem and area at the top of the hill are very interesting and the outside areas are great to explore.

Castle Museum. You need to be interested to spend time here or it is not worth a visit. This is not a casual walk through as there is a lot of information to take in. Young children wold be bored. But, if you are interested in the history of the castle then it is really good and there is plenty to keep you engaged. The displays are well presented with information panels in English.
Impressive. Packed with beautiful scenaries and breathtaking architecture and views. A must-see when in Budapest!

You have to see it but it is very touristified. It is impressive - and being converted to accommodating the Hungarian prime minister Orban - enough said. I would just say that apart from being impressive, the road and pavement surface is not very good for buggies or wheelchair users.

Walk up to the top, don't be ripped off by the ride.. We saw the tourists catching the lift to the top but are glad we didn't blindly follow. The views as we were ascending were astounding, and there were many photo opportunities. Once we reached the top we were able to see the changing of the guard and spent 3-4 hours wandering through to all of the attractions. The souvenirs and restaurants were of course overpriced and poor quality- tourist traps to be sure.

Beautiful. Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful views. Getting there is quite easy, either by taxi or on foot, using the walk or funicular. Visit to get to the cathedral and fisherman's bastion, worth it.
Plenty to see. The entire area deserves a full day to do it justice and is the number one tourist area on the Buda side of the Danube. So many photo opportunities around every corner.
Interesting. Full of history and museums, with interesting buildings and nice views over the town, also nice just to walk around

Worth the walk up!. We walked up here on our last day in Budapest and it was one of the best things we did. The walk isn't as steep or hard as it looks and well worth it (don't bother with the furnaculars!)The view from the top was incredible - you essentially get to see all of Budapest at once and take in the river Danube. It's also a great place to explore Buda from.We almost didn't visit during our trip but I'd urge every other traveller to make the effort!!

Lovely views. Not worth getting the funicular up the top unless you are mobility impaired as it is very expensive for effectively a 1 minute experience (think it was about 1300 forints but please correct me if I'm wrong) the view at the top is lovely, worth a walk around. The views of the Danube are stunning from up here

A must see when in Budapest. Castle Hill is a beautiful area and a must see if you're visiting Budapest. Plan to have several hours if you're on the Pest side. Cross the Danube on one of the bridges and then either take the funicular, if it's open, or climb the stairs to the Castle area and just stroll around looking at the beautiful buildings and enjoying the view back to the Pest side of the river. Lots of places to sit and have refreshments and enjoy the beauty of the city.
Only in night or in sunny day. Good pleace for one hour walk, great views, you have also drink coffe in caffe tarase, or get same photos in panorama view

Used a morning to stroll on Buda Hill for photo stops of its attractions. The attractions on Buda Hill were clustered together in 3 areas: the Matthias Church/Fisherman's Bastion, the Royal Palace, and around the Vienna Gate. We visited the Matthias Church (entry fee) which had stunning interiors, but the rest were mainly photo stops as we strolled by them. We walked from one end of Buda to the other end during our morning visit to Buda Hill.Definitely, the highlight of our visit to Buda hill was the square with Matthias Church and Fisherman's Bastion. There was a 1200 Huf entry fee to see the interior of the Church but it was so unusual and memorable it was worth it. Fisherman's Bastion itself was stunning for its fairytale appearance and its panorama views over the Danube towards Pest. We could see clearly the Parliament building, St. Stephen's Cathedral, the bridges, St. Margaret's Island, the city of Pest, and even a bit of Gellert Hill. Being clustered together, the attractions on this square saved us a whole lot of walking time. We allowed 1 1/2 hour for the visit to this square.Another cluster of attractions included those around the funicular landing and the Royal Palace: the raven statue, the Royal Palace now an art gallery and Museum of History, the Palace courtyard with its entry through the wrought iron gates, the Palace fountains and statues, the views over the Danube, and Sandor Palace for the changing of the guard. All of these were just photo stops for us. We allowed ourselves 20 minutes. The fountains in the courtyard were less impressive, less interesting, and smaller than I imagined them to be. At the beginning of June, there were few flowers to make me want to stay longer than just a quick walk by. Probably this courtyard would be sufficiently viewed from the ornamental wrought iron gate. Nearby was the black raven statue. The raven had its wings spread wide with individual feathers visible, and a golden ring in its mouth. Without knowing the significance of the raven to the royal family, one certainly wonders why the bird is given such prominence. The raven was a motif of the royal family and used in their coat of arms as a family crest. It symbolizes King Matthias. A bronze raven was also perched atop one of the shorter towers of Matthias ChurchThere was a third cluster of attractions at the other end of Buda: the Vienna Gate, the Museum of Military History, Mary Magadene Tower, and Erdody Palace. We walked on Toth Arpad Setany to reach this area. This promenade which runs parallel to the walls of medieval Buda had trees for shade, a few benches, and views towards Gellert Hill. This walk was too long with little to see until we reached its end. There were, also, few side streets so we couldn't change our walking route. There were other streets to walk on to reach Vienna Gate so give those a try. The Mary Magdalene Tower was worth the walk in order to see the ruins or footprint of a church and its tower that was once used by both Catholics and Christians for services during Turkish rule. On our way back, we walked along Orszaghaz street which had side by side houses (some very old and noted for their appearance) and shops where I bought some packaged smoked paprikia (1500 Huf). This road led us back to the square with Matthias Church. We quickly located the stairs behind the church at the Fisherman's Bastion that led down the hill to the town at its base. Our stroll and return to the town at the base of the hill took about 1 hour. If visits are required to Buda's museums, the art gallery or even the attraction, Hospital in the Rock, at the base of the old town walls, visitors could use up a day rather quickly. At night the Royal Palace is splendidly lit up along with Matthias Church, Fisherman's Bastion, the Parliament, and other sights along the Danube River. I would definitely recommend taking a Danube cruise at night to see this spectacle. It was a free ride for us on our Scenic river cruise ship. It's easy to get to Buda Hill. Perhaps we could have saved time and energy by taking the funicular from Clark Adams ter to the top of Buda Hill. However, we walked past the funicular to the arched patio area where a ramped path, escalator, and elevator took us to the castle courtyard for free. On our return to the town at the base of the hill, we found that the wide stairs at the Bastion led to more and more downward stairs until we reached the town where I wanted to see the Church of St. Ann. The attractions on Buda Hill had entry fees between 1200 to 1800Huf with the Hospital on the Rock being the most expensive at 3600Huf for an hour's visit.
Must Visit. A must visit when in Budapest to know more about their history and culture. Building is nice in and out.

Gardens and Castle. The Castle area has beautiful gardens with lovely flowers. the place is so relaxing and the castle is a structure to admire.
Not sure if one is allowed inside, our group only walked around the castle and lawns and enjoyed it never the less

Majestic castle hill. On the Buda side of the city, there is a little hill, there are plenty of attractions from churches, to museums, restaurants - take care they are very expensive! - hotels etc. Once this was the seat of the Hungarian monarchs. You can walk around and you find buildings from the middle age too. It is really something you can't miss in Budapest

Make the effort . Well worth exploring the Pest side. This is one of the main attractions. Picasso exhibition on now, and not too busy compared with many other cities. Take in the great views 100% recommended.

amazing view, but could be better. I've been in Budapest a number of times through the years and have always come up to Castle Hill for the wonderful view over the Danube, Pest, the Parliament, etc. The older district near Matthias Church is pleasant, although it seems to me to have become far more touristy through the years. Shops here are pricey compared to elsewhere, in my opinion. We walked as a family up Gellert Hill and then down and over to Castle Hill. Perhaps a 15-20 minute walk from the bottom of Gellert to the Castle. I was surprised by how poorly maintained the area was. Even within the grounds of the castle, most of the gardens were overgrown, with lots of broken bottles and other trash about. This was surprising, and I didn't encounter anything like this anywhere else in Hungary. The Castle itself is largely a reconstruction, and a flawed one at that. But the view is still amazing and worth coming for. The public buses that serve the area near the castle, connecting it to Ferenc Deak ter, are wonderful. Would recommend this to all, but would hope that maintenance improves!

History you can walk through. You have to stop by and read the signs and other historical markers to get some perspective that this has been a dynamic castle through the ages. Good long walk on a nice day, but I wouldn't bother in poor weather.

Disappointing up close. In three previous visits to Budapest I had never made it up the hill here, so on my most recent trip I decided to give it a go. Playing "Spot the Tourist Trap" is easy as soon as one steps off the tram line at the local stop, as you spy long queues of British, German, American, and other tourists all queueing in the heat to be ripped off for the vernicular railway up the side of the cliff; meanwhile there is a perfectly accessible stairway and free lift just around the corner. Once you have made it to the top - for either 1,000 Forint or for free, your choice - the views of the city are not bad, but dwarfed in excellence by the views from the nearby Gellert hill. The walk along the wall can be vertiguous, especially with its low walls and sheer drop, which makes it probably the most exciting thing about the top of the palace. The architecture is nice to look at, but no different to most of the other romanticised buildings down in the centre of Pest.Perhaps the biggest disappointment, however, was the museum. It was peak time in the middle of an afternoon at the end of Spring when we visited... And the museum was closed. A simple sign was posted over the entrance saying no admittance today, with no explanation as to why. As a result, the entire rear area of the castle was deserted and felt slightly derelict in comparison to the crowded front. The cafe and ice cream parlous was open, but equally and expectedly overpriced as the vernicular. Because of these reasons, I would say that this is something worth doing just to say that you have been up there; if you have a spare few hours and have exhausted all your other options. Bring your own drink up to the top on a hot day though, and remember that everything you need to pay ridiculous amounts of money for can be done either for free or more cheaply elsewhere.

Impressive Views and Architecture. We came to the Pest side using a Hop on Hop off bus. We stopped at both stops for the allotted hour touring and this was enough at each stop. If you plan on entering buildings you should leave yourself more time. Trails were good for walking and the views from the high points amazing. The statues that you see from Buda are amazing. There are places for drinks and eating and souvenir buying, Definite stops on your visit to Budapest. Beautiful at night.

Stunning views. Lovely area with lots to see and the views are amazing. It is a very busy area with tourists and therefore has all the usual souvenir shops. Plenty of cafes and restaurants. It is well worth a visit to see the other side of the city
Disappointing. From the Pest side of the river this castle is very impressive and a stunning view, but up close and personal not much of it and the cafe is a little bit over priced.

Quick walk aroind. The present exhibit is a Picasso art exhibit which doesn't interest me. It is still fun to take the funicular either up or down. The cars are beautifully maintain old fashion cars with a great view of the Chain bridge. There are two courtyards of statues to see and great views of the city.

A town within a town. Worth the walk up just for the views. The little town was quite a different atmosphere to Pest. Didn't go in the castle so can not comment about the inside, but surrounds wonderful
So much to do!. Spend a few hours up there. You will find the castle, the palace, Budapest labyrinth, Fisherman's bastion and St Stephen's church. Great views and lots to do.

Not just a castle. Castle Hill is an entire region including a cathedral, the fisherman's bastion, a museum and the castle. You could spend an entire day here walking around. We took a crowded city bus up the hill, but the funicular might be a better choice. This is great tourist stop.

Spectacular Views. The views from castle hill are something else - not to be missed. Go early - we arrived at 9am and beat most of the crowds. Funicular is a good option on a hot day but lines become unmanageable by mid morning. Go around the back - few people do this yet there are lovely sights.
Fabulous area. Always something new to find. This whole area is awesome. Great buildings, good restaurants, fabulous atmosphere. We walked here every day and didn't bore of it.
A must-see. This is one of the top attractions in Budapest and visiting Castle Hill, you will see why. It is magnificent. The architecture is fantastic and the views are even better.

One of the highlights of the trip. If you like panoramic views of cities then this is your stop. You can take lift or take some steps up to the castle. Just amazing history and building. It glows lovely and night and it's awe inspiring in the day.

It is a MUST. Please if you are hesitating to visit the Vár (Castle) just take the time and go!It worth it. Probably if you would like to see everything including the museums you can spend a full day here. There are many nice restaurants where you can take a rest. If you don't have that much time, then at least take 3 hours to be able to walk around, and see most of the places.

Should have spent more time. We really only saw the big cathedral up on Castle Hill and I wish we'd had more time for some cafe sitting and visiting other sites. It's a lovely view of Pest, the cathedral is stunning (do pay to go in) and it is an appealing area for tourists. You can easily walk over from Pest if you're walking all over the city anyway. Stair access is super easy if you don't want to pay for the funicular.
Stunning viewing point. From here you can practically take different panorama pictures of the city and still enjoy the beautiful view without no stress
Worth the walk. As with all the other places in Budapest this is a lovely place to visit, the views from up here are spectacular and the gardens are beautiful
great view, impressive. beautiful location, lots of opportunities to walk (without entrance-fee). nice bar and restaurant with fabulous view. very accessible and friendly atmosphere.

Interesting Area. Castle Hill is a World Heritage site on the Buda side of Budapest, It has the castle itself, Matthias church and the Fisherman's Bastion. Walking up to the top of the hill you past a few cafes and restaurants and nice souvenir shops. There are also private residences. The area itself is free to the public but you must purchase a ticket to visit Matthias Church and climb up the Fisherman's Bastion.

Stunning views of Budapest!. We visited Castle Hill whilst in Budapest and were not disappointed. The views of the city from up here are absolutely stunning. Thanks to another Tripadvisor review, we found a set of lifts/escalators which take you to the top in a matter of seconds - otherwise you can take the funicular railway but there was a really long queue for this when we visited which doesn't go down very quickly. There was a Picasso exhibit going on when we went, which we didn't go to, instead we enjoyed the views and there is a nice cafe where you can get a beer and some light food. Would consider going back to do a proper tour of the palace.
Lovely area. Lovely area - good views of the Danube, lovely buildings and a nice walk along beautiful streets. See the Matthias Church and Fisherman's Bastion while you are there.

Bloody steep hill. Amazing views and amazing interior and exterior. The views are amazing. I would recommend the bus option to the top if you don't enjoy steep walks. But it is incredible when you get to the top. A few cafes and market stalls at the top but the junk is more than double that of the same stuff in the market!!

Castle Hill . One of the many sights that must be visited in Budapest. Great walking destination. Cross the Chain Bridge and take the funicular to the Castle. Lovely architecture and statues. Wonderful views across the Danube to the Pest side.

use funicular to get up there. It was very hot when we visited. It's on top of a hill so advisable to use funicular. There are some cafes, an art exhibit and a museum. It has lovely views over Budapest but if you need a toilet you need to pay for the experience.
amasing view.. Breath taking view of budapest. Easy to get via fisherman bastation with lift and escalators. Impressive castle.

Lovely building and some fantastic art. We were so fortunate on our visit as there was a Picasso exhibition running at the same time. We bought a combined ticket which enabled us to see a huge range of art and a full Picasso exhibition at an incredibly low price.

See while you can. Go see this treasure of Hungarian (and world) history while it's still open to the public. The palace buildings currently house the National Library, museums and art exhibits. Museum night is a specialty, so are all folk festivities like the one around August 20 or artist markets at various times taking up the streets. Stroll on the narrow alleys, peak into courtyards and admire centuries-old architecture, enjoy a snack or a meal in one of the cafes and restaurants or stay at the Hilton with the unbeatable view of Pest. The Fisherman's Bastion and the Matthias Church with porcelain tile roof are other gems of Hungarian cultural heritage on the hill.
Spectacular at night!. This area is beautiful both during the day and at night. It boasts an amazing view of Budapest and the Danube. Definitely worth visiting.

lots of walking around the outside. The inside of the castle is not open; they are in the midst of renovations which will take years. However, the views from outside of the castle are spectacular and you can walk around almost the entire castle to get a feel of its size and its history.

Awesome, Imposing and Inspiring. You could just visit the grounds and be impressed by the stunning architecture and the awesome views of the Danube and the city below, but there's much, much more to it. Visit the National Gallery and the special exhibit next door of Picasso's artwork (til July 31). At hand a few hundred meters, the castle district beckons- the Fisherman's bastion, St. Mathias church and more. Don't miss it. If open, you can ride the funicular to the top.

Great view of Budapest. The castle is a beautiful sight in itself, but the added views of the city makes this a must see in Budapest. If you have the time, take the walk from Gellert Hill to the Castle, or the other way around. It's gorgeous.

One of the best views of the city!. The hill has a long walk that covers many major sights of the city. The museum for the Hungarian art is a must and the views of the river and the Pest side are excellent!
Love the architecture in Budepest. One reason I love Budapest is for its architecture. And Castle Hill is a big part of that.. has great views of the Danube and Parliament on the other side.
Beautiful castle. The castle has so many wonderful features, a must see on your itinerary. Love the funicular ride to the top of the hill.
Gorgeous from every angle. I took the funicular up and could have walked around for hours if i haD more time. This was my favourite.

Castle Hill. On the Buda side, above Chain Bridge, on everybody's list of things to do and see on the Buda side. Some boutique shops and pedestrian streets surround the area. The main cathedral is usually booked for weddings on the weekends and thus not open to the public. Lot of stuff to see from the outside, however. Worth the trip even if on a weekend
Nice views. Nice place for romantic walking. Top of the hill with a castle is available by a funicular from bank of the river.

Truly majestic and beautiful, needs time to appreciate. On the Buda side towering on a hill looking down on the danube.If your feeling fit, then there are lots of walkways and steps from the street but fully accessible also by lifts and the Funicular railway to the right of the building from the river side.Several good restaurants on site also so you can spend a leisurely day there if you have the time.

Beautiful site, especially at night!. The title says it ALL! Budapest is simply loaded with amazing architecture and wonders of the world, but such a secret to the Americans. History should not be forgotten. Let us all visit Eastern Europe, who has worked so hard to recover from WWII and the difficulties under the Soviet Union.

Nice Area to Stroll around. Rebuilt after the War and thoughtfully restored, its just nice to stroll around the perimeter taking in the views across the Danuble to 'Pest' A nice cafe to people watch. Art Gallery and several notable statues and an elaborate fountain within the whole complex

Another Lovely Site in Budapest. I am in love with Budapest and this lovely edifice is part of the reason. At night the highlights of the city are brightly lit and the effect is spectacular. I regret that I was not in the city long enough to actually visit this site up close and personal, but I will next time

Worth queueing for the funicular.. Beautiful views from the hill. great art gallery. Nice little coffee bar in the grounds. Nice walk to the surrounding area with some good restaurants and very interesting church.
Great views. You can ride a funicular up the hill by buying a ticket or take the steps. Once you get up there you will have great views and many picture taking opportunities

Gorgeous view of the city during the day and at night.. We stayed at the Hilton on the Hill and loved walking around at night when it was nice a quiet and safe. There were not many cafes or bars open after 8 though. The view was perfect and better at night with the lights all.
Attractive view. Its located on a hill that you can see the whole city. Must see! Its very close to the bridge. You can take many photos from here. You can see the bridge and parliament from above.

Worth a visit, but not great. Not very special, though worth a visit. Lots of construction (and excavation) going on. Did not go into any of the buildings...maybe that would have made it more gratifying

A short and invigorating walk across the Danube. I believe most tourists stay on the Pest side of Budapest. Walk along the chain bridge and than either queue up for the funicular or climb the steps to the top of the hill/Castle District. There is the beautiful National Museum with a special Picasso exhibit; the Fisherman's Bastion and a couple of other sites plus many souvenir shops and restos abound. Definitely worth a visit.
A must. Great views of the city especially at night, The historical heart of the city. Nice places to eat there. It can get crowded during the day

Come here during the Easter holiday. We were here during the Easter season and all of Budapest turned into a giant outdoor market and fair. It is full of families and happiness and Castle Hill was one highlight. There is an old world festival here with simple but excellent games and rides and attractions and shows. This was a wonderful way to spend part of our holiday. I can't recommend spring/Easter season enough in this city.

Castle Hill....So beautiful, so much history, and so worth the visit!. We did the Castle Hill/Parliament half day tour. There's a lot to see here. The Royal Palace, and our favorite the Mathias Church with its beautiful colored tile roof! Its over 700 years old and don't miss the beautiful Fishermen's Bastion. You'll find great opportunities for taking some great photos in this area!

Not special but it's a nice place to take a walk during night.. I've lived in Hungary and visited here so many times. It's always better at night. Visiting the castle itself is free, dunno about the ticket price for museum tho. Many people use the hill funicular but I don't think it's worth it. The way up is pretty short anyway so if you are in good shape why not walk up?
Amazing. Walking a lot to go to the top. There is option to take bus(something like bus) but you have to pay.Amazing view to the city and to the Dounavis.

Not my favorite. I have been to several castle hills in Europe and this was not a favorite of mine. In fact, I like Prague, Krakow, and Salzburg much more. Unfortunately, most of the buildings were destroyed in WWII and when rebuilt they did not restore the original interiors. You have an art museum, history museum, and a library now. They are OK and the art museum has some nice pieces but it's not the same as visiting a restored castle/palace. Some of the other sights on the hill reviewed elsewhere were a bit more interesting and the sights were worthwhile.

Beautiful.. This area of "Budapest" is my favorite. Take time to check out the fountains in the courtyard, the beautiful roof top on the church and the views from the Fisherman's Bastion. Cheapest water on the hill is probably in the Prima grocery store, so grab a drink and enjoy the day.

Worth Visiting. The view along is amazing! Worth it just for that. There are lots of steps, but there is an escalator or Venicular. The Vernicular is fl1800 return (just less than £5). If you book the Giraffe Hop On, Hop Off bus, you get the Venicular for free. Once inside they have exhibitions (about fl1800 - just less than £5), with concessions according to age (up to age 26, from age 62) to less than £2. There is also a Hungarian Museum, but this was closed so we don't know if they also charge. There's also a few little log souvenior kiosks, a cafe, cloakroom and wc.
Great views. The view from the top is amazing. It's worth the climb. Although there is a cable car that goes up. It's a must!

Take the tram up to Castle Hill.... A beautiful building that houses the national art gallery. We took the time to see the Picaso exhibit while there, along with many other fascinating displays of art.

Well worth a visit!. This is a beautiful area with incredible views and a must see on a visit to Budapest. Getting there is quite easy, either by taxi or on foot, using the walk walk or funicular. There are lots of nice places to eat and drink, so stick around for lunch and enjoy the atmosphere.

Beautiful building by the day, gorgeous by night. Easy approach by hop on hop off or furnicular and offers best views of the Pest side and the Danube including the chain bridge and the parliament building. Visit to get to the cathedral and fisherman's bastion too and prepare to do a fair bit of walking, worth it.

Pleasant morning at the castle. Went up in the cable car and was just in time for changing of the guard. A full performance by a whole squad of soldiers, very entertaining. Walked all round the museums & walls at the top. Some fantastic views of Pest, Parliament & Danube. Well worth a visit.

Quaint area to walk around. Lovely area to stroll, enjoy a coffee or gelato and take in wonderful views. You can easily spend a day touring this side of the river
Free to walk around. There is a local bus that will take you to the top of the hill

Nice views... still under renovations. Having been destroyed in WWII and not a priority of the Russians, this area seems to be very slow to rebuild. The Prime minister's office is next to the castle and it was fun to watch the changing of the two guards. There is an archeological dig right behind the castle so walking is tricky. There is a nice size bar in front of the castle with music and a very small garden area.

Another beautiful view of the city. The interior of the castle is interesting, but do not expect a very spectacular art collection in it. The most interesting thing about this place is actually observe the view from up there, and walk calmly through the gardens on a sunny day.
Great views . Beautiful architecture Great views across the city from a high vantage point Take plenty of time to walk around and explore

Historic Hiitop. For most visitors the Castle District is perhaps the first stop on sightseeing. Royal Castle, Fisherman´s Bastion, Matthias Church or the Mythical Bird"Turul" can be easily reached by funicular or by foot. Hugarians -or original Magyar tribes- settle atop the castle hill already in the 13th century building as castele and making Buda their capital. Arriving by funicular the Royal Palace is the frist attraction is a sprawling complex of wings, coutyards as well as cultural instituans; constructe in a mixture of styles but primarely in Renaiossance style built by Maria Theresia the Austro-Hungarian empress in the 1700-ies a 200 room Building. After visint the castle Mathias Church and Fisherm,an´s Bastion nearby. Today`s Palace accomodate Hungarian National Gallery, Library and History Museum.Another Major attraction of castle hill is the tradition-rich Ruszwurm´s famous pastry shop known for its moutuh-watering ice creams, strudels, pstries and other enthuisiastic culinary delights resurrecting flavors from the past recreated in forms of today`s tastes and ingredients.

The oldest part of Budapest. The Castle hill is the oldest part of Budapest. Her you can find old Buildings and a lot of Restaurant in the Backyards. The Castle and the "White House of Budapest" (the Residence of tht President) is also located here. The Castle contains the Budapest Historical Muzeum, the National Galery and als the Szecheny Libary. .

A good way to spend a morning and look out over Budapest. We reached this via the restored cliff railway, worth a visit in itself. The views from the top are spectacular. Budapest is an old city with no high rise, The Art gallery is vast with traditional and modern exhibits. We had a good beer overlooking the Danube but not great food at the other cafe. The Early woodcarving and altarpieces are splendid but other wise this is not a world clad gallery in our opinion.

Nice but not astounding. We took the bus up to the top as the funicular car was not working that day. We enjoyed walking around the Buda hill with its history however all seemed rather commercialized. A half day here is more than enough.

Castle HIll. A high point of the city affording beautiful views of Pest across the Danube - ride up in the funicular and walk along the palace walkways. Go back down through the lovely palace gardens. If you have the time, visit the exhibition in the Palace itself.

Chocolate box tourist trap. Fairy tale sights & sounds. Fairy tale setting. Chocolate box lid photo ops. But...... Disneyland is more genuine. Partially through necessity, partially through cynical tourism artifice, this is a cynical exercise in money making. Your average 'model village' has more veracity than this 1&th century confection. Worth a visit? Of course. Just don't believe all you see. In fact, don't believe ANY of what you see.....

Tourist central. Castle Hill is very crowded, and rightly so. A spectacular location overlooking the Danube River, it provides wonderful views of the City as well as the architectural and historical highlights of the vicinity itself. A must visit spot on any itinerary in Budapest.

Rural tranquillity amidst the city . Visit the Castle Mountain for its history, its atmosphere etc. It's very special.A very special place that is somewhat similar in atmosphere to the Athens Acropolis Hill and Plaka.

Nice View. There was a lovely view of the Danube and the whole city from the balustrade. There is a charming village also on castle hill but as you'd expect it's extremely pricey... Worth a look for sure!
Beautiful. Beautiful cobbled streets, great sightseeing, lots do nice cafes, bars and restaurants. Very clean and pleasant place
A little piece of Disneyland on the Danube. A guided tour of the castle is worth the money as all is not what is seems. The castle itself is very grand, photos do not do it any justice.

The best views in Buda. A ‘must see’ area on the Buda side of the city with fabulous views. A great way to visit is to take the nearby funicular and walk the short distance to the castle. Allow a minimum of an hour to walk around, longer if you intend to eat.Don't just stay around the castle area with the Matthias Church but take a walk around the adjoining quiet streets to see some lovely buildings where there are lots of classy restaurants. This is; a great area for a special meal, particularly in the evenings when the crowds have diminished.Excellent public toilets near the access to the castle area (small fee payable in forints or euros).Expect crowds during the daytime.

Interesting place with spectacular views.. We only had a few hours in Budapest while we were waiting for our flight home so decided to visit the old town Castle Hill and were not disappointed. The views of Budapest are spectacular and the buildings and grounds were very well kept. We went inside the church for a small fee and were surprised at how noisy it was with various tour guides giving commentaries, which was a shame given it was a church. It was fascinating to see almost every inch of the walls and ceiling were painted, something we don't see in churches in England. We also saw the changing of the guard at the old government building, which was interesting to see, although nothing like changing the guard at Buckingham Palace! The only negative comment we had was that you had to pay for use of the toilet, which only having Romanian currency was a problem. It would have been nice given the amount of money people were paying on food, drinks, ice creams etc in the area for the toilets to have been free to use. We would definitely recommend it and will pay another visit when next in Budapest.
Walk around the grounds. We went up to Castle Hill, and I recommend the funicular as a fun experience with nice views. Did not enter the Castle, but it is worth a stroll.

Beautiful building but shame about the organization. I can not fault the beauty of this building and the grounds were lovely. How ever there was parts we could not walk, and were told but security we had to walk around and then told by another security (once we had walked around) we could not walk this way and had to go back! We could not go in the castle at all or even get near it. There were no signs or any person to explain why. It is probably a very nice place inside.

Castle on the top of the city. The Castle on the Buda side Oldtown is one of the diamonds of the Hungarian Capital. Not just the view and the building itself, but an amazing garden, nice statues and montains and the National Gallery and food/vine festivals taken place here.
tourist spot. this is a standard tourist attraction which one does when one travels to a budapest. good place to spend time .
Great views of Pest. Beautiful neighborhood and walk. It has great views of Pest from the hillside and is a great way to get an aerial shot of Budapest. Recommended.

Must see!. I visited the Buda castle after late lunch. It has beautiful palace and if you're visiting at sunset, you can definitely enjoy the beautiful scenery of Budapest at a glance. It is a MUST SEE!

Some of the most beautiful views in East Europe. We wound up here after a walking tour which started at the Wombat's hostel. After crossing the Danube via the Chain Bridge and walking up some paths towards Castle Hill, the tour ended at the Unesco World Heritage site. We were left to walk around free and just enjoy the historic settings and magnificent views of the Danube. We never did make it to the castle itself, but were still extremely satisfied with literally everything else this beautiful little place had to offer! May 2013

Our guide drove us up, we might have missed it. Beautiful neighborhood, lovely architecture. Great photo opportunities. Since most signage is in Hungarian it is very helpful to have a guide show you around. The city views are incredible. Shops, restaurants, St Matthias church, monetary ruins, Hilton Hotel, and today a beer festival!

Stunning views. We decided to take the funicular railway up the hill the first time which gives you great views of the Danube. Everywhere you go on castle hill you can see far and wide across Budapest. You get a chance to see some of the older, more traditional Budapest. We didn't go into any of the buildings as it was really nice weather we just wanted to meander round. One gripe is that you have to pay for the toilets and not only were they some of the more expensive toilets in the city but they were some of the dirtiest.

Amazing View . You have to do a trip to the castle. The view was just amazing. You can drive up or walk. Both is really nice. At the top you can see both sides of Budapest. Just aaaaamazing! So if you visit Budapest you have to go their!

Views. Lovely views, lots of steps though. Buildings are amazing, new mixed in with old nicely. Plenty places to eat and drink, reasonable priced. Can get very busy. Felt relaxed walking around, not bothered by any one.

Interesting. High on the hill, this can be reached by one of the City Tour Buses or the funicular.Well worth a visit, when we were there a Picasso exhibition was taking place. The other exhibits and the architecture etc are well worth seeing.
amazing place...go ahead and walk skip the tram. The castle area is great...well worth the trip. The walk up is easy if you want to skip the lines on the tram. Fantastic views and architecutre
Part of the Spectacular View. Although stunning by day, Castle Hill is spectacular when viewed at night. Take a stroll along the Danube to enjoy it fully.
Too modern too please.... Due to the age of the castle it was not of our taste and there was a festival about to start so men were erecting dozens of "sheds" for concessions.

Great Views. The Fishermans bastion provides wonderful scenic views of Pest which include the Parliament Building. Take the veniculare up. Worth the wait. If you are a Roman history buff then you'll see some ruins of Aquincum after the exit from the veniculare. Unfortunately no information was posted about these ruins. There is also an Jaime Oliver eatery too busy when we got there.

City break to Budapest. Lovely area of the city providing stunning panoramic views. I would recommend using one of the city tour buses to visit this area, especially if you are elderly/infirm. Or you can reach it easily by using the funicular at the Buda side of the Chain Bridge. This castle now also houses the National Gallery. Well worth the trip for the views alone.
Lovely area. Used the Hop on , Hop off buses which took us to all these areas. The Castle area is beautiful, over the Buda side of the river and spent a whole day there

Better Soon.... Yes, the views are incredible and the location alone would have gained a better rating but they are currently under construction and made the visit much less enjoyable. The overwhelming sounds, thwarted views, and overweight workers without shirts really diluted the experience. Simply put, it would be far more ideal to visit at a better time.

The Buda side of the city.. The Buda side of the city is very historic and beautiful to walk around on a spring day. The area at the castle and the promenade. The other really amazing thing about Budapest is the enormous and grand scale of the statues.
The best view in Europe. I have been in many European Capitals but you never find such a picturesque view on the city like from the Castle District. Must go and must see!

The view makes you speechless. Looking at the Pest side from one of the highest points of Buda, the Habsburg's palace is just amazing. A 300 degree view on the whole city, with the silver ribbon of the Danube, the beautiful bridges and islands, the famous sites, monuments all sticking out of the Pest-side plane. Go for a walk along the 600--years old city walls, stroll the streets of old Buda castle, the cobble stone streets (no high heels!) with remains of the various periods dating back the 1300s. From the backside of the castle area enjoy the view of the Buda side, the soft ondulating hills, greens and some beautiful buildings. Visit one of the many museums or just go for a coffee or glass of wine sitting in the sunshine. Touristic but for a very good reason!
An essential part of any visit. Impressive day or night and beautiful when lit up at night. Vast building but you only get access to a small part in the museum.

Interesting area, very historical with beautiful views of the Danube. We biked down Castle hill on the cobblestones and it was quite an experience. The winding road was very interesting! Views from the top were spectacular in both directions, interesting shops and beautiful interiors at the top of the hill.
Stunning views of Budapest.. Take the short funicular ride up to the castle. The views are spectacular and it is well worth watching the changing of the guard.

Make sure you allocate plenty of time. We visited the castle over 2 days. The first day we walked up to the castle via the route next to the elevator. The queue for the elevator was huge, we walked around the castle and exited via the west exit. On the second day we crossed margit bridge and entered the castle via the east side. The castle is vast and has a bus service that takes you to the top but we only found this after the second day. There are a number of shops, restaurants and cafes along with all the historic monuments. There are some great views from the top and is definitely worth a visit. Be prepared for a steep climb and wear suitable shoes.

Stunning at every turn. Day one of our trip and we did a lot of exploring in the Buda area, the walk up to the palace and fishermens bastion was lovely (despite being 6 months pregnant) I did think it looked a little daunting on a hot day but really wasn't an issue!!The views and architecture were just beautiful, we instantly fell in love with the city by visiting this area.
Nice view. Nice view on the city. The hill itself looks amazing in the night, when all the lights are on and it's dark. Especially seeing it from the nearest bridge.

What a fantastic place to spend a day. There are several sites to see on Castle Hill, and you should try to take in as many as possible. Save a good portion of a full day for roaming and exploring. Start by taking the funicular up from its base at the Chain Bridge to get a view of the Danube and Parliament. Then wander the Castle, take in the museums, snap shots of Fisherman's Bastion, and definitely visit Matthias Church. Eat at one of the fine local restaurants. We had wild boar goulash and chicken with dumplings. Yummmmm.

A lovely walk and amazing views.
