The area near the castle (Royal Palace - National Gallary & museum) is the most difficult to navigate, but does offer some lovely views and some beautiful architecture too. We attempted to go to the museum, however we entered the building and saw, to our left a large flight of steps and although there were several staff watching us, none came to offer advice or help; we decided that we wouldnt bother and left, so if you need access advice try getting in touch direct in advance.The funicular is accessable and either wheelchair user or carer (not sure which) does not pay. We were there at lunch time and saw the changing of the guard which took place at the building to the right as you come out of the funicular station; this was ceremoniously preceeded by a bugle call. Worth it if you are around the area at lunchtime.There are some stalls selling souvineers (quite expensive for what they are) along there also, but this is one of the most cobbly bump bits in that area, and the stalls occupy a little area of smooth path, so it is worth having a look to get some releif from the cobbles for you and your assistant.There are lots of lovely little shops, cafes, etc, but most are either up or down a few steps and with narrow entrances making access difficult.Up at the other end of the Hill is the Fishermans bastion (see seperate review) and Matthias Church, the area between these areas is slightly up hill but not a problem, but the area around fishermans bastion becomes cobbly again, although not as difficult to navigate as that at the palace area.It was a nice area, very picturesque, and if you are not staying in that area allow poss 3 hours to do it all. There are toilets in a few places but I did not see any accesable toilets, however there are accessable toilets in the lobby of the Hilton hotel, so maybe just head there.

Beautiful place! Count your change when taking the funicular up to Castle Hill.. The views are amazing! It's really one of the nicest spots in Budapest and a must-see for anyone visiting. However, if you are thinking of taking the funicular to get up the hill, be sure to check your change properly before taking it in your hands. We were not given the right amount of change, and when we pointed this out to the cashier, she got angry, repeated the amount the tickets cost, and when she flipped the rotating tray back to us, there were two additional coins there. Her rudeness was also not appreciated, because my sister was very politely and gently saying that the change was too little, in no way was she aggressive, and the lady probably thought she was an easy target. It may not be a large amount of money (tiny, compared to the amount we were overcharged by a taxi at Castle Hill) but I really hate people who try to take advantage of tourists.

Amazing view and museums. It would be more appropriate to call this review "The Castle District", as it is known in Budapest.You can take the Varhegy bus from Moszkva ter or the furnicular railway by the Chain Bridge. I normally walk up. No matter how many times we go, I can always find something new to look at. There are the beautiful old houses, posh cake-shops and wine cellars and of course the Castle itself. The Hungarian National Library, the magnificent Matthias Chrurch and the National Gallery can be found here. Occasionally they have wine festivals here as well. There are even archeological sites around.The view from the Castle overlooking the Danube is amazing. Always reminds me of my favourite poem "... as if flowing from my heart, the Danube was murky, wise and grand."

Beautiful and Romantic ;). This is by far the most pretty and best kept parts of Budapest.The church, the castle, the cobbled roads and small stalls/shops selling local crafts and even the quaint little coffee shop selling cakes and sandwiches was gorgeous.We spent a whole day here and it was our best memory of Budapest. It was gorgeous weather too which helped massively. Dont miss it, you'll love it.

Nice to see, but was expecting more. The main thing to see in the castle is the Fisherman's Bastion, which is a really nice view point from the castle walls. You can also walk up and enter the castle grounds this way. There are also a lot of statues there and the Matthias Church, but this was under renovations when we went. There isn't much to see on the north side of the grounds, because the houses are still inhabited! On the south side, there is the old Royal Palace, which is now converted into two museums. Really nice grounds and really good funnel cake!!
Great wiew and nice castle but.... Great wiew and nice castle but don'tspend more than 3h over there!

The most beautiful part of Budapest. While the Castle itself, dominating over the Danube, is a little disappointing (I expected something mor ancient), the Castle Hill area is gorgeous with its winding streets, historic townhouses and stunning views over Buda and Pest. It is here that you feel history.

Lovely place to spend a view hours. The streets are really pretty and its a nice place to wander around and take pictures. There was some sort of ceremony with horses & traditional costumes in the main square when we were there. It was quite windy when we were up there & I think it is more open to the elements so be careful what the weather is doing.

Lovely views and beautiful buildings. We went up the left side of Castle Hill, it kinda felt like a really long windy driveway. It was a great walk and there were some neat stone areas along the way (be careful not to fall, there are no guardrails there!). The castle itself is now a museum and we didn't actually go in it, but we did walk around and enjoy the fountains, statues, and beautiful buildings. Once at the top we walked through a main archway and to the right where there were street vendors (one selling 6 different flavors of funnel cakes, yum! We just followed the smell). After that we saw where the prime minister lives, walked along the streets and saw lots of shops and then arrived over at Fisherman's Bastion.It's a really easy walk up the hill, but you could take the funicular if wanted to avoide a climb. We had a lovely time just walking along. Plus it's all free (except the funnel cake).
